Tidy Data

A tidy data set is a standardized way of organizing data that makes it easier to manipulate, analyze, and visualize. The concept was popularized by Hadley Wickham, a prominent statistician and developer of the R programming language ecosystem.

Key Principles of Tidy Data

  1. Each variable forms a column.
    A variable is a measurable attribute (e.g., temperature, age, price).

  2. Each observation forms a row.
    An observation is a single instance or case (e.g., a personâ€™s measurement at a given time).

  3. Each type of observational unit forms a table.
    Different entities (e.g., people vs. companies) should be in separate tables.

Example: Non-Tidy vs. Tidy

Non-tidy:

NameMathScience
Alice8590
Bob7888

Tidy:

NameSubjectScore
AliceMath85
AliceScience90
BobMath78
BobScience88

Why Tidy Data Is Useful

  • Easier to manipulate using tools like pandas (Python) or tidyverse (R).
  • Compatible with most data visualization libraries.
  • Facilitates better data cleaning and transformation workflows.

entry.content:
CPACC Study Notes: Theoretical Models of Disability

Overview

In accessibility and disability studies, theoretical models offer different perspectives on what disability is and how society should respond to it. Understanding these models is critical for CPACC certification and real-world accessibility practice.

1. Medical Model

  • Definition: Views disability as a problem of the individualâ€™s body or mind that needs to be cured or managed through medical treatment.
  • Example: A person using a wheelchair canâ€™t enter a building due to stairsâ€”the issue is seen as their inability to walk.
  • Strengths:
    • Recognizes medical needs.
    • Supports development of clinical treatments.
  • Weaknesses:
    • Ignores environmental barriers.
    • Can be disempowering.

2. Social Model

  • Definition: Sees disability as caused by an inaccessible society, not the personâ€™s condition.
  • Example: That same person using a wheelchair is disabled by the lack of a ramp, not their body.
  • Strengths:
    • Focuses on changing environments and attitudes.
    • Empowers people with disabilities.
  • Weaknesses:
    • May underplay the importance of medical needs.

3. Biopsychosocial Model

  • Definition: Combines biological, psychological, and social factors to give a complete picture of disability.
  • Example: A person with chronic pain may have physical limitations, emotional distress, and face work challenges.
  • Strengths:
    • Holistic and balanced.
    • Useful in rehabilitation and care planning.
  • Weaknesses:
    • Complex to implement.
    • Risk of shifting focus too far from either medical or social realities.

4. Economic Model

  • Definition: Focuses on the economic impact of disabilityâ€”on the individual, employer, and society.
  • Use Case: Often used to determine eligibility for disability benefits.
  • Strengths:
    • Highlights the need for financial and workplace accommodations.
  • Weaknesses:
    • Can be stigmatizing.
    • May exclude those who donâ€™t meet strict legal definitions.

5. Functional Solutions Model

  • Definition: Focuses on solving practical problems caused by functional limitations, often through technology or design.
  • Example: Using voice recognition software for someone with limited hand movement.
  • Strengths:
    • Action-oriented and practical.
  • Weaknesses:
    • May overemphasize tech solutions without addressing systemic issues.

6. Social Identity / Cultural Affiliation Model

  • Definition: Views disability as part of a personâ€™s identity and cultureâ€”most clearly seen in Deaf culture.
  • Strengths:
    • Fosters pride and community.
  • Weaknesses:
    • Can exclude those who donâ€™t identify with a specific group.

7. Charity Model

  • Definition: Sees people with disabilities as objects of pity who need help from others.
  • Strengths:
    • Can motivate people to provide aid in emergencies.
  • Weaknesses:
    • Disempowering.
    • Often leads to short-term rather than systemic solutions.

Statistical Reporting in User Research

Basic Statistical Terms

Mean and Standard Deviation

  • M (Mean): The arithmetic average of a group of values.
  • SD (Standard Deviation): A measure of how spread out the numbers are from the mean. A low SD indicates values are close to the mean, while a high SD indicates more variation.

Likert Scale

  • A psychometric scale commonly used in questionnaires.
  • Usually ranges from 1 (Strongly Disagree) to 7 (Strongly Agree).

Parametric Statistics (å‚æ•°ç»Ÿè®¡)

(Repeated-Measures) ANOVA

  • Format: F(df_between, df_within) = value

In a dependennt sample, the same test units(persons,animals..) are measured several times under different conditions(time points,treatments).

  • F: The F-statistic measures the ratio of variance between groups to the variance within groups.
  • p-value: Indicates the probability that the observed result is due to chance.
    • A p < 0.05 suggests statistical significance.
  • r (Effect Size): Measures the magnitude of the difference.
    • Small: ~0.1
    • Medium: ~0.3
    • Large: ~0.5+

Example:

ğŸ“˜ Common Statistical Terms and Methods in User Research

ğŸ“Š Key Statistical Indicators

1. F-statistic (F)

  • Used in: ANOVA (Analysis of Variance)

  • Purpose: To test if there are statistically significant differences between group means.

  • Formula:
    F = variance between group means / variance within the groups

  • Example:
    F(1,15) = 10.024

    • The first number (1) is the between-groups degrees of freedom (df between)
    • The second number (15) is the within-groups degrees of freedom (df within)
    • 10.024 is the F-value â€” the larger it is, the more likely the group means differ.

2. p-value (p)

  • Purpose: Measures how likely it is that the observed results happened by chance.

  • Threshold:

    • If p < 0.05, the result is considered statistically significant.
    • If p < 0.01, itâ€™s highly significant.

  • Example:
    p = 0.006 means thereâ€™s only a 0.6% chance the result is due to random variation.

3. r (Effect Size)

  • Purpose: Describes the strength or magnitude of an effect or relationship.

  • Common thresholds:

    • 0.1 = small effect
    • 0.3 = medium effect
    • 0.5 or higher = large effect

  • Example:
    r = 0.633 is a large effect, meaning the observed difference is not only statistically significant but also practically meaningful.

4. M (Mean) and SD (Standard Deviation)

  • M (Mean): The average value of a dataset.

  • SD (Standard Deviation): Measures how spread out the data is from the mean.

  • Example:
    If valence scores are M = 7.47, SD = 1.01, it means:

    • The average score is 7.47
    • Most scores fall within Â±1.01 of the mean (6.46 to 8.48)

5. H-statistic (H) â€” Kruskalâ€“Wallis Test

  • Used in: Non-parametric tests for comparing 3 or more independent groups.
  • Purpose: Like ANOVA, but for non-normally distributed data.
  • Example:
    H(3) = 29.240
    • 3 = degrees of freedom = number of groups â€“ 1
    • 29.240 is the test statistic

6. U-statistic (Mannâ€“Whitney U test)

  • Used for: Comparing two independent groups (non-parametric version of a t-test)

  • Purpose: Test whether the distributions of two groups are significantly different.

  • Example:
    U = 25.656, p < 0.001 â†’ One group significantly outperforms the other.

âœ… Summary Table

TermTypeWhat it Tells You

pAll testsWhether result is statistically significant
rEffect sizeStrength of relationship
M / SDDescriptiveMean and variation in scores

UNon-parametricTwo-group difference (Mannâ€“Whitney)

ğŸ§ª Experimental Designs

7. Repeated-Measures Factorial Design

  • Purpose: All participants go through all conditions of the experiment.
  • Advantage: Controls for individual differences by using the same participants across conditions.
  • Example:
    A 2Ã—2Ã—2 design (System Ã— HMD Ã— Experience):
    • System: ShareVR vs. Baseline
    • HMD: HMD user vs. Non-HMD user
    • Experience: Game A vs. Game B

8. Latin Square Design

  • Purpose: To counterbalance the order of conditions and reduce order effects (fatigue, learning, etc.)
  • How it works: Each condition appears exactly once in each row and column.
  • Example (4 conditions):

$$
\begin{matrix}
A & B & C & D \

B & C & D & A \

C & D & A & B \

D & A & B & C
\end{matrix}
$$

Each participant pair follows a different rowâ€™s order.

ğŸ§® Non-parametric Methods

9. Aligned Rank Transform (ART)

  • Purpose: Allows ANOVA-style tests on non-parametric data.
  • Why use: For factorial designs where assumptions like normality and equal variance are not met.
  • Benefit: Keeps the flexibility of ANOVA but suitable for non-normal data.

10. Kruskalâ€“Wallis Test

  • Used for: 3 or more independent groups, non-parametric version of ANOVA.
  • Input: Ranked data instead of raw scores.
  • If significant: You need a post-hoc test to find out which groups differ.

11. Dunnâ€“Bonferroni Post-Hoc Test

  • Used after: A significant Kruskalâ€“Wallis test.

  • Purpose: Compares each group pairwise, while correcting for multiple comparisons using the Bonferroni correction.

  • How: Adjusts the significance level (Î± / number of comparisons)

  • Example:
    You compare 4 groups. Thatâ€™s 6 comparisons. Bonferroni correction sets the new p-threshold at 0.05 / 6 = 0.0083.

ğŸ® Summary of Standardized Questionnaires for User Experience in Virtual Environments

These widely-used questionnaires help researchers systematically evaluate gameplay experiences, emotional responses, and the feeling of presence in virtual or shared environments. Hereâ€™s a breakdown of the most common tools.

ğŸ§© 1. Game Experience Questionnaire (GEQ)

The Game Experience Questionnaire (GEQ) is a comprehensive tool for measuring how players feel during and after gameplay. It captures both emotional reactions and cognitive involvement through several modules.

ğŸ”¹ Core Module

Assesses the immediate personal experience during gameplay, typically using a 5-point Likert scale (e.g., from â€œNot at allâ€ to â€œExtremelyâ€).

ğŸ˜© TirednessPhysical or mental fatigue caused by the experienceâ€œI felt exhausted after the game.â€
ğŸŒ Returning to RealityDifficulty re-adjusting to the real world after immersive playâ€œI needed time to adjust after the game.â€

ğŸ”¹ Social Presence Module (Optional)

Focuses on interpersonal dynamics in multiplayer or co-experience settings.

SubscaleDescriptionExample Item
ğŸ¤ Behavioural InvolvementHow much attention a player gives to their co-player(s)â€œI closely followed what the other person did.â€
ğŸ’“ Empathy & Emotional ContagionEmotional resonance and feeling what the other feelsâ€œI felt connected to the other person emotionally.â€

ğŸ’¡ Use Case: The GEQ is ideal for measuring moment-to-moment and retrospective gameplay experiences across single or multiplayer settings.

ğŸ˜Š 2. Self-Assessment Manikin (SAM)

The Self-Assessment Manikin (SAM) is a quick, non-verbal, and intuitive tool to measure usersâ€™ emotional states in response to stimuli (games, media, VR, etc.).

ğŸ“ Dimensions

Participants select a cartoon-like figure on a scale for each dimension.

DimensionDescriptionExample

ğŸ§  Insight: SAM is useful when you want a lightweight emotional assessment â€” especially when working with children, cross-cultural users, or those unfamiliar with Likert scales.

ğŸŒ 3. Slater, Usoh, and Steed (SUS) Presence Questionnaire

The SUS Presence Questionnaire is specifically designed to measure how â€œpresentâ€ or immersed someone feels in a virtual environment (VE).

ğŸ§  Psychological Components

ComponentWhat It ReflectsSample Item
ğŸ“ Place IllusionSense of â€œbeing thereâ€ physicallyâ€œI felt I was really inside the virtual environment.â€
ğŸ§  Plausibility IllusionHow real the scenario feels mentallyâ€œThe scenario seemed like it could really happen.â€
ğŸ‘ï¸ Attention/InvolvementFocus level in the VE, ignoring real-world distractionsâ€œI concentrated entirely on the virtual experience.â€

ğŸ” Insight: SUS helps researchers understand presence as both a sensory and psychological phenomenon, making it essential for VR studies.

ğŸ§­ When to Use What?

  • ğŸ•¹ï¸ GEQ: In gameplay studies to assess engagement, fun, and player fatigue.
  • ğŸ˜ƒ SAM: For quick emotional feedback, especially in media or UX studies.
  • ğŸ•¶ï¸ SUS: When evaluating presence in VR, e.g., comparing headsets or systems.
